original_title: Sri Lanka to delay debate on central bank bill
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka Parliament committee will meet later Tuesday and decide on a new date to debate a draft law on reforming the island’s central bank, Prime Minister Dinesh Gunawardana said following request by Opposition Leader Sajith Premadasa.
“The matter can be discussed at the business committee meeting and re-scheduled for another date,” Prime Minister Gunawardana said
The controversial new central bank which is set to legalize output gap targeting (stimulus or printing money for growth) under so-called flexible inflation targeting framework.
The passing of a new central bank law is a requirement under an International Monetary Fund agreement.
Opposition Leader Premadasa said the opposition Samagi Jana Balawegaya agreed that the central bank should operate without political interference, but more discussion was needed on the bills.
He had spoken to President Ranil Wickremesinghe on the phone earlier in the day and he agreed to defer the bill.
“I requested President to give more time to discuss and arrive at a bi-partisan consensus,” Premadasa said.
“I thank him for agreeing. He told me to state this in parliament.”
The bill was originally scheduled to be debated on May 11. (Colombo/May09/2023)
